However that gap remains and it will remain until such a point that the fundamentals either change or there's a good reason for the markets to revisit that point. The second form of access is tails, now we get two types of tails, the first is the invisible tail. Now it's a relatively simple but very important sort of market access to consider. When we have a normal tail you would be able to identify quite easily on a volume profile because it sticks out. Now an invisible tail doesn't quite stick out that easily, but all an invisible tail is, is it's a very aggressive auction within the day's range. It's where market very quickly initiates from one point to another and continues to initiate. An invisible tail is nothing more than an initiative move taken by the buyers or sellers but within the already established range of the day. And I will show you an example of this in the next slide, so do not worry too much if you don't understand the invisible tail. Then obviously the open tail or what we like to think of as the high or the low or the extreme tail, an example we saw back in part 6. Now the open tail is the tail left within the first hour of trade, so the initial as it shows us early confidence in the market to move toward the upside or to the downside. So now we've discussed these three basic forms of excess, the reason we're discussing them is because these forms of excess give us early identifiers, they give us an early indication of potential movement toward the up or the downside.
